qas.question: What comes before state and territorial laws in the 50 U.S states?
Federal sovereign only possess authority if it is stated in what?
States may grant their citizens border rights as long as they do not infringe on what?
Most U.S law, the kind of law we live everyday, consists of what kind of law?
Does every state have the same laws?

answers.text: vary greatly from one state to the next.

qas.question: Federal law overrides what laws?
The scope of federal power is not what?
What type of system is American Federalism?
American Federalism can also be considered tripartite because of the presence of what?
States can grant their people broader rights than those granted in what document?
Is there anything that trumps state law?
How many state make up the United States?
Can states grant rights to citizens that are not defined by the constitution?

answers.text: as long as they do not infringe on any federal constitutional rights

qas.question: What is day-to-day, operational law considered?
What is living law mostly made up of?
State and territorial laws preempt what kind of laws and treaties?
The scope of what is considered universal?
What type of government system do Indian reservations have?
States may grant citizens fewer what?
What are examples of family law?

context: <a0_0><a10_0><b15_0>Federal<b15_0/> law and treaties<a10_0/><a0_0/>, so long as they are in accordance with the Constitution, preempt <a5_0>conflicting state and territorial laws<a5_0/> in the <a11_0>50<a11_0/> U.S. states and in the territories. However, the scope of federal preemption is limited because the scope of <b16_0>federal power<b16_0/> is not <a6_0>universal<a6_0/>. In the <a7_0>dual-sovereign system<a7_0/> of American federalism (actually <b17_0>tripartite<b17_0/> because of the presence of <a8_0>Indian reservations<a8_0/>), states are the plenary sovereigns, each with their own constitution, while the federal sovereign possesses only the limited supreme authority enumerated in <a1_0>the Constitution<a1_0/>. Indeed, states may grant their citizens broader <b18_0>rights<b18_0/> than <a9_0>the federal Constitution<a9_0/> <a12_0>as long as they do not infringe on any <a2_0>federal constitutional rights<a12_0/><a2_0/>. Thus, most U.S. law (especially the actual <a13_0>"living law"<a13_0/> of <b19_0>contract, tort, property, criminal<b19_0/>, and family law experienced by the majority of citizens on a day-to-day basis) consists primarily of <a3_0><a14_0>state law<a14_0/><a3_0/>, which can and does <a4_0>vary greatly from one state to the next.
